At that time, the peacock king Bodhisattva, knowing the minds of the heavenly multitudes, further proclaimed the sixteenth Dharma for them, and said to the heavenly multitudes:
'There is also a good Dharma, a delightful Dharma, that can restrain carelessness just like an iron hook, and one should remember to practice it.
What is the good Dharma?
It is called mindfulness of death.
If a person is mindful of death, always diligently practicing without ceasing,
there is a great evil that is unequaled, which disturbs all sentient beings, and no one can escape it, and no one can avoid it.

Those who are born will certainly die. It can cause all loved ones to be separated, cause people to perish, and be reborn in different places. Some are born in a place of suffering from a place of happiness. Bound by the rope of karma, supported by their own karma, they fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
At the time of death, there are no companions, only good and bad karma as companions.
Good karma is like a parent, leading one to a place of happiness;
Bad karma is like a great enemy, leading one to hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
For this reason, one should cultivate good karma and abandon evil.
If one can cultivate mindfulness of death in this way, the mind will not be attached to objects, and will not be attached to greed, anger, or delusion.
Out of fear of death, one will not create unwholesome karma for the sake of wife, children, or relatives.
If those in the householder stage can cultivate this mindfulness, they will still attain tranquility, let alone those who have left the household life.
If monks cultivate mindfulness of death, they will not violate precepts, will not delight in objects, and will not dwell in confusion.
If one dwells in confusion, the mind becomes scattered, the basis of much speech, and one sees many women.
One should abandon all places that give rise to greed and lust, and contemplate death.
If one is in a noisy and chaotic place, the mind is not good, and at the time of death, one will obtain all kinds of harm and distress, and not attain peace and joy.

At the time of death, one is cut apart by the wind of the knife and the wind of the sword, without refuge or rescue. Bound by the rope of karma, one is led to another world. Neither parents, siblings, wife, children, nor relatives can save and protect one.

If one is able to cultivate the contemplation of the signs of death in this way, such a person will enjoy upholding precepts and wisdom. Such practice will then enable good karma to increase and bad karma to be eliminated. Due to good karma, one will experience the bliss of humans and gods, and later attain nirvana.
If men and women know of these merits, whether at home or ordained, whether Å›ramaá¹‡as or brÄhmaá¹‡as, they should always contemplate death.
Because of mindfulness of death, the mind is fearful and does not create any unwholesome karma. The mind thinks like this:
All sentient beings will return to death. In the realms of gods, humans, hell, and hungry ghosts, there is no place without death.
If one is able to cultivate mindfulness of death in this way, fearing the future, the mind will not be attached to form, sound, smell, taste, or touch.
Such objects are impermanent, not unchanging, and not subject to destruction. Always contemplate impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
If the mind contemplates death, it will not be disturbed by evil. Always frequently cultivate the contemplation of impurity, and let it grow well.
Frequently contemplate death, cultivate and let it grow, and focus the mind on impermanence.
There is no permanent place that is not subject to destruction, change, or cessation.
Even the peaks of beloved mountains, millions and billions of them up to Mount Sumeru, will be destroyed by the conflagration at the end of the eon, let alone the bodies of humans and gods.
The great ocean has no boundaries, and all the great rivers and the abodes of all the dragon kings, all the dragons and asuras, when the seven suns appear, will all dry up, let alone my body.

In brief, the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm, all the three realms are impermanent, changing, and will all be destroyed, let alone my body and life being permanent, unmoving, indestructible dharmas?'
If one is able to always keep this in mind, to observe with a good mind, to cultivate the mind in this way, there is no place to take pleasure, no place to crave, no place to be angry.

Because of the purity of greed and anger, delusion also follows and ceases. Because of being free from the three faults, one attains the foremost state, which is not old, not dead, not exhausted, not extinguished.
Thus, mindfulness of death has no object of mindfulness. Therefore, mindfulness of death is the foremost of all mindfulness.
'Cultivating the characteristics of mindfulness of death also has merits.

As for my body, the body and mind are afflicted by illness, destroyed by old age, taken away by the king of death, bound by the net of death, what can be done? I am unable to practice giving, uphold precepts, and cultivate wisdom.
Therefore, before death arrives, one should practice giving, upholding precepts, and wisdom. Death will soon arrive and destroy the life of all beings.

Furthermore, mindfulness of death means that this body is impermanent, all conditioned things are impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, changing moment by moment, quickly passing by, subject to destruction, empty and nothing, not a solid dharma, like a whirling fire wheel or a gandharva city, and all conditioned things are also like this.
My body and life are also like this, without solidity, like water bubbles or a gandharva city.
Such a law of death exists for all, and it will definitely come, it is very frightening;
Therefore, one should cultivate solid dharmas, gather the three wholesome actions, and abandon the three unwholesome ones.
One should think like this and contemplate the thought of death.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as cultivate this in their own minds, by cultivating this thought they will attain great benefits.'

Furthermore, the seventeenth Dharma that can greatly benefit Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as - what are those dharmas?
Namely, abandoning conceit based on physical appearance, family lineage, and wealth.

If one has conceit based on physical appearance, family lineage, and wealth, then this foolish person will engage in evil deeds with the mouth, body, and mind. Due to these causes and conditions, when the body perishes and life ends, one will fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animal realms, and will transmigrate in those places of birth, experiencing immeasurable suffering and birth and death, which cannot be described.
Having already understood the faults, one should not give rise to conceit based on physical appearance, family lineage, and wealth.

If there are people who can be free from arrogance about their appearance, their family background, and their wealth, one should know that such people will not create evil karma with their body and speech. They will see appearance as impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self. It is empty and nonexistent, without solidity. It is an impure vessel, a combination of hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, and flesh, with countless bone chains, sinews, marrow, fat, and flesh, filled with feces, urine, pus, and blood.

This physical body of mine is also impure at the beginning, impure in the middle, and impure at the end. It is born from countless causes and conditions of karma and afflictions. It is without solidity, impermanent, unreal, and without self.

Now, when this body of mine reaches the time of death, it will not be my companion even for a single step. It will be abandoned in the charnel ground, either burned by fire or eaten by vultures, crows, owls, foxes, dogs, and other animals.
If a person contemplates and recollects in this way, the arrogance about appearance will either be extinguished or diminished.
Furthermore, if Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as give rise to pride in their family lineage, saying:

Because of foolishness, one falsely gives rise to discrimination, thinking:

This family lineage is inferior.
This is not so in reality.
Why is it so?
Because there is birth, therefore there is lineage, and such changes occur.

That person, although born in a low lineage, is called a great lineage.

If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and other practitioners contemplate their physical appearance, although there is physical appearance in infancy, it is not the appearance of a motionless face, and the appearance of motion is not the appearance of crawling. At that time, the king of geese, having thought this, with a pure mind benefited the celestial multitudes. With a compassionate mind, he contemplated the mind of supreme perfect enlightenment, and went to the place where the celestial multitudes received the five desires, and stayed there surrounded by the multitudes of geese.

Seeing the heavenly beings playing in the mountains and forests, either roaming in flower gardens or roaming in palaces covered by branches and leaves, or sitting in jeweled palaces in the sky, or some heavenly beings eating the taste of Sudha together with the heavenly maidens.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Swan King had this thought:
Now is the right time to speak the Dharma for the heedless gods.
I will now use my beautiful voice to sing verses, overshadowing the singing voices of the gods and goddesses.
The gods and goddesses are attached to desire and heedless, unable to hear the Dharma. Hearing my voice, their ear consciousness will love it and they will definitely come to me.

Having had this thought, he emitted a wonderful sound, contemplated the merits of the Buddha, gave rise to a mind of compassion, ascended the seven-jeweled mountain, surrounded by a flock of swans filling ten yojanas, with an incomparable beautiful voice, he spoke in verse, saying:
And while death has not yet arrived, one should practice and cultivate merit and virtue,
Do not preserve your own life, lest you regret it later.
If one engages in heedlessness, it is called the place of death;
If one practices heedfulness, it is the foremost way of immortality.
If one engages in heedlessness, this path is not of cessation;
It is by relying on heedfulness that wisdom attains nirvana.
The heavenly multitudes should not be heedless, for heedlessness is not of cessation;
Because of practicing what is not of cessation, one will fall into hell.
Whether one has already lost, will lose, or is presently losing,
It is all due to the fault of heedlessness, as the TathÄgata has said.
Therefore, at all times, one should diligently apply effort,
Far removed from heedlessness, one will attain the Dharma of cessation.
In this way, the Bodhisattva Swan King ascended that mountain peak and spoke these verses with a beautiful voice, overshadowing the singing of the celestial maidens, whose voices became unmelodious.
At that time, the assembly of gods, hearing the voice of the Swan King, all gave rise to love and joy.

Everywhere on the mountain, all the gods had never experienced such a thing before, thinking it was the sound of singing - with a mind of attachment, not respecting the Dharma - all came to the peak of the mountain and arrived where the Swan King was.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Swan King again spoke verses, as mentioned above. When the assembly of gods, sons of gods, and daughters of gods heard his voice, their minds all followed along.
In this way, the Swan King, when he was among humans, was the son of a great elder named Utpala Datta. He heard the true Dharma from Kanakamuni Buddha and was reborn here.
